problems.title: Operations with Inversions
problems.statementHtml:
Given an array a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an. In one operation, you can choose a pair of indices i,ji,j such that 1≤i<j≤n1≤i<j≤n, ai>ajai>aj, and remove the element at index jj from the array. After that, the size of the array will decrease by 11, and the relative order of the elements will not change.

Determine the maximum number of operations that can be performed on the array if they are applied optimally.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤501≤t≤50). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (1≤n≤1001≤n≤100) — the size of the initial array.

The second line of each test case contains nn natural numbers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the maximum number of operations that you can perform on the given array.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, we can first choose the pair i=2i=2, j=3j=3 with values a2=2a2=2, a3=1a3=1 and remove a3a3. The resulting array will be a=[3,2]a=[3,2]. After that, we can remove the second element by choosing the pair i=1i=1, j=2j=2. The total number of operations is 22.

In the second, third, and fifth examples, no operations can be performed since there are no suitable pairs.

In the fourth example, we can remove the second and fifth elements. It can be shown that this is the optimal answer and there is no solution that removes more elements.

problems.title: Optimal Shifts
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a binary string s1s2…sns1s2…sn, containing at least one 1. You want to obtain a binary string of the same length, consisting only of 1s. To do this, you can perform the following operation any number of times:

Choose a number dd (1≤d≤n1≤d≤n) and consider the string tt as a cyclic right shift of the string ss by dd, or, more formally, t=sn−d+1…sns1…sn−dt=sn−d+1…sns1…sn−d. After that, for all jj for which tj=1tj=1, perform sj:=1sj:=1. The described operation costs dd coins, where dd is the chosen shift amount.

Note that the positions jj in the string ss, where initially sj=1sj=1, remain equal to 11 even if tj=0tj=0.

You need to determine the minimum number of coins that can be spent so that the string ss consists only of 1s after all operations.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains the number nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105) — the size of the given binary string.

The second line of each test case contains a binary string of length nn, each element of which is either 0 or 1.

It is guaranteed that at least one character in each string is equal to 1.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn across all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the answer to it — the minimum possible number of coins that you can spend to make all characters in the string equal to 1.
problems.noteHtml: Consider the third example, where s=s= "0110". In this case, it is optimal to choose d=2d=2, then t=t= "1001". After that, at positions j=1j=1 and j=4j=4, sjsj will be replaced with 1, resulting in the string ss consisting of all ones. Note that the cost of this operation is d=2d=2.

problems.title: Odd Process
problems.statementHtml:
You have nn coins with denominations a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an and a natural number kk. You also have a bag, which is initially empty, where you can place coins. You need to perform exactly kk actions. In each action, you take one coin from those you have left and put it in your bag. After that, you can no longer take that coin.

At the same time, you have a cat that loves even numbers, so every time the sum of the denominations of the coins in your bag becomes even, your cat empties the bag, meaning it takes all the coins to a place known only to it, and the bag is empty again. Note that the bag is emptied every time the sum becomes even during the process of adding coins, not just at the very last moment.

Let your score be the sum of the denominations of the coins in the bag. Your task is to perform kk actions such that your final score is maximized. Find the answer for all 1≤k≤n1≤k≤n.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of coins you have.

The second line of each test case contains nn natural numbers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1091≤ai≤109) — the denominations of the coins.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn across all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output nn numbers — the maximum possible score that can be achieved by performing exactly kk actions for all kk from 11 to nn.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first set of input data, you have coins with denominations [1,1,11,1,1].

  • k=1k=1: in this case, the sum of the denominations in the bag is 11, regardless of the chosen coin. The final score is also 11.
  • k=2k=2: in this case, the sum of the denominations in the bag is initially 11, regardless of the choice of coin. When choosing the second coin, the sum will be 22, regardless of the choice of coin, and thus the bag will be emptied. The final score is 00.
  • k=3k=3: in this case, when choosing the first two coins, the sum will be 22 and the bag will be emptied, after which the sum will be 00. When choosing the third coin, the sum will become 11.

In the second set of input data, you have coins with denominations [1,2,31,2,3].

  • k=1k=1: in this case, when choosing the coin with denomination 22, the bag will be emptied and the final score will be 00. When choosing the coin with denomination 11 or 33, the final scores will be 11 and 33, respectively. The maximum possible final score is 33.
  • k=2k=2: in this case, when choosing two coins 11 and 33 in any order, their sum will be 44, after which the bag will be emptied and the final score will be 00. However, when choosing 33 as the first coin, the score will be 33. Then you can choose, for example, coin 22, and the final score will become 55.
  • k=3k=3: in this case, the sum of all coins will be 66, and since each time the bag is emptied it does not change the parity of the accumulated sum, the final score is 00.

problems.title: Fibonacci Paths
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a directed graph consisting of nn vertices and mm edges. Each vertex vv corresponds to a positive number avav. Count the number of distinct simple paths∗∗ consisting of at least two vertices, such that the sequence of numbers written at the vertices along the path forms a generalized Fibonacci sequence.

In this problem, we will consider that the sequence of numbers x0,x1,…,xkx0,x1,…,xk forms a generalized Fibonacci sequence if:

Note that a generalized Fibonacci sequence consists of at least two numbers.

Since the answer may be large, output it modulo 998244353998244353.

∗∗A simple path in a directed graph is a sequence of vertices v1,v2,…,vkv1,v2,…,vk such that each vertex in the graph appears in the path at most once and there is a directed edge from vivi to vi+1vi+1 for all i<ki<k.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two numbers nn, mm (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105, 1≤m≤2⋅1051≤m≤2⋅105) — the number of vertices and the number of edges in the graph, respectively.

The second line of each test case contains nn natural numbers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤10181≤ai≤1018) — the numbers written at the vertices.

The next mm lines contain the edges of the graph; each edge is defined by two natural numbers v,uv,u (1≤v,u≤n1≤v,u≤n, u≠vu≠v), denoting a directed edge from vv to uu. It is guaranteed that there are no multiple edges in the graph.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn and the sum of mm across all test cases do not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the number of paths that form a generalized Fibonacci sequence, modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
Explanation of the first test case example (the vertex number is outside the brackets, the number written in the vertex is inside):

In this case, there are 5 generalized Fibonacci paths: (1,21,2), (1,31,3), (2,42,4), (3,43,4), (1,3,41,3,4). For example, for the path (1,3,41,3,4), the sequence of numbers written at the vertices along this path is: [3,3,63,3,6]. As can be easily seen, the third number in the sequence is the sum of the two previous ones.

Explanation of the second test case example:

In this case, there are 9 generalized Fibonacci paths: (1,21,2), (1,41,4), (2,32,3), (2,42,4), (3,13,1), (3,43,4), (1,2,41,2,4), (2,3,42,3,4), (3,1,43,1,4). Note that for the path (1,2,31,2,3), the sequence of numbers written at the vertices along this path is: [1,1,11,1,1], and it is not a generalized Fibonacci sequence.

problems.title: Remove at the lowest cost
problems.statementHtml:
You have nn elements. Each of these elements has a natural value aiai and a natural removal cost cici. You need to remove all elements except one, paying the minimum possible cost. To do this, you perform the following operation n−1n−1 times:

In one operation, you choose two adjacent elements and remove the one with the smaller value. For this operation, you pay the removal cost of the least expensive element among the two. If these two elements have equal values, you can remove either of them, paying the removal cost of the minimum of the two in terms of removal cost. After removing an element, the elements to the right of the removed element shift left by one position, leaving no gaps.

You also have nn zeroing operations for the removal costs of the array. After the ii-th zeroing operation, the removal cost of the element with index pipi becomes 00. It is guaranteed that all pipi are distinct. You need to solve this problem for the original elements, as well as after each of the zeroing operations.

Note: After the ii-th zeroing operation, the removal cost of the element pipi remains 00 in all subsequent problems (i+1,i+2,…,ni+1,i+2,…,n).
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains one natural number nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of elements you have.

The second line of each test case contains nn natural numbers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1091≤ai≤109) — the values of the elements.

The third line of each test case contains nn natural numbers c1,c2,…,cnc1,c2,…,cn (1≤ci≤1091≤ci≤109) — the removal costs of the elements.

The fourth line of each test case contains nn natural numbers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn (1≤pi≤n1≤pi≤n) — the indices of the elements whose removal costs are zeroed, in the corresponding order. It is guaranteed that all pipi are distinct.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn across all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output n+1n+1 numbers — the minimum cost of removing all elements except one, before all zeroings and after each of them.
problems.noteHtml:
Explanation of the first test case example:

The minimum cost of removing all elements before zeroings is — 42.

To achieve this cost, you can, for example:

  • Remove the first and second elements of the array for a cost of 33. These are the elements (5,105,10) and (5,35,3) — (value, cost)(value, cost). Then we can first remove the element (5,105,10) for the cost of the second element — 33, since the value of the second element is equal to the value of the first. Next, we can choose the remaining element (5,35,3) and the element (8,98,9) (the third in the array before removal). The value 5≤85≤8, so the element (5,35,3) is also removed for a cost of 33.
  • Remove the last two elements of the array (5,105,10) and (5,35,3). They are removed similarly for a cost of 33.
  • The remaining elements of the array can be removed using, for example, the element (10,610,6) — the fourth element in the original array. The value of this element is greater than or equal to the values of all remaining elements, so all remaining elements of the array can be removed for a cost of 66. The element (10,610,6) itself will not be removed and will remain as the last element of the array.

The total cost of all removed elements is 3+3+6+6+6+6+6+3+3=423+3+6+6+6+6+6+3+3=42. It can be proven that achieving a lower cost of removing all elements except one is impossible.

After the first zeroing request, the first element becomes (5,05,0). Now the first two elements can be removed not for 3+33+3, but for 0+00+0. The total cost of removing all elements except one is now 3636.

problems.title: Omega Numbers
problems.statementHtml:
For a given number nn, consider the function ω(n)ω(n), which is equal to the number of unique prime numbers in the prime factorization of the number nn.

For example, ω(12)=ω(22⋅3)=2ω(12)=ω(22⋅3)=2. And ω(120)=ω(23⋅3⋅5)=3ω(120)=ω(23⋅3⋅5)=3.

For an array of natural numbers aa and a natural number kk, we define f(a,k)=∑i<jω(ai⋅aj)kf⁡(a,k)=∑i<jω(ai⋅aj)k for all i<ji<j.

You are given an array of natural numbers aa of length nn and a natural number kk. Calculate f(a,k)f⁡(a,k) modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains 2 integers nn and kk (1≤n≤2⋅105,1≤k≤1091≤n≤2⋅105,1≤k≤109) —the length of the array aa and the exponent of the operation, respectively.

The second line of each test case contains nn natural numbers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n) —the array aa.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn across all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single line containing an integer — the value of the function f(a,k)f⁡(a,k) modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
Explanation of the first test case example:

For any pair (i,ji,j), the value ω(x)ω(x) for the product is ω(32)=1ω(32)=1. There are a total of 66 pairs, and the exponent is 11. The final answer is 66.

Explanation of the second test case example:

In any pair of the second test case, the product of the numbers in the pair equals 11, so the number of primes in it is 00. Therefore, the final answer is also 00.

Explanation of the third test case example:

Consider all pairs (i,ji,j):

  • (1,21,2): the product of the numbers at positions 11 and 22 equals a1⋅a2=1⋅2a1⋅a2=1⋅2, ω(2)=1ω(2)=1.
  • (1,31,3): the product of the numbers at positions 11 and 33 equals a1⋅a3=1⋅3a1⋅a3=1⋅3, ω(3)=1ω(3)=1.
  • (1,41,4): the product of the numbers at positions 11 and 44 equals a1⋅a4=1⋅4a1⋅a4=1⋅4, ω(22)=1ω(22)=1.
  • (2,32,3): the product of the numbers at positions 22 and 33 equals a2⋅a3=2⋅3a2⋅a3=2⋅3, ω(2⋅3)=2ω(2⋅3)=2.
  • (2,42,4): the product of the numbers at positions 22 and 44 equals a2⋅a4=2⋅4a2⋅a4=2⋅4, ω(23)=1ω(23)=1.
  • (3,43,4): the product of the numbers at positions 33 and 44 equals a3⋅a4=3⋅4a3⋅a4=3⋅4, ω(3⋅22)=2ω(3⋅22)=2.

In the answer, the values of ω(x)ω(x) are raised to the power of 22, so 12+12+12+22+12+22=1212+12+12+22+12+22=12.

tutorial.contentHtml:
Thank you all for participation! We hope, you enjoyed the problems.

2176A - Operations with Inversions

Hints
Hint 1

Which element of the array cannot be removed using the described operations?
